summary: swabs or sputum specimens were obtained from patients suspected of having pertussis on the day of hospitalization. the specimens were tested with the filmArray Respiratory Panel, a multiplex polymerase chain reaction assay that detects 16 viruses, Bordetella pertussis (B. pertussis), Mycoplasma pneumoniae (M. pneumoniae) and Chlamydophila pneumoniae (C. pneumoniae) pertussis remains one of the top ten fatal infections in children (4). typical clinical symptoms include repeated paroxysmal cough, an inspiratory whoop and post-cough vomiting (5). a resurgence of pertussis in the post-vaccination era has been reported in developed countries despite high vaccination coverage. the standard laboratory diagnostic criteria for the identification of B. pertussis include culture, polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assays and serodiagnosis (13-15) the culture of nasopharyngeal secretions is currently the gold standard for pertussis diagnosis. however, given the harsh growth conditions, the detection rate of culture remains low. Respiratory Panel (FilmArray RP, v1.7) is able to detect 16 viral and 3 atypical respiratory pathogens, including B. pertussis, in a single test. the multiplexed nature of this test enables the rapid differentiation of B. pertussis from other viruses that also cause pertussis-like syndrome. the positive rate of B. pertussis detected by filmArray RP is 6.3% (49/775) in the whole setting and 35% (49/140) in pertussis suspected patients. a total of 851 patients with RTIs were screened in a previous study. discharged. this suggests early diagnosis and macrolide treatment play important roles in the treatment and prognosis of pertussis. previous studies have shown that pertussis infection in children sometimes mimics viral RTIs. at present, most of the PCR-based assays target the insertion sequence (IS481) for B. pertussis detection (51-54) IS481 is internally repeated >50 times in each B. pertussis genome. the genetic target for B. pertussis in the FilmArray RP is the promoter region of the PT gene. the present study describes the current status of B. pertussis infection in china. it highlights the need for timely and accurate diagnosis based on both clinical symptoms and laboratory methods.
